Seed Treatment is one of the most vital components of Integrated Pest Management in Crop Protection. Application of insecticides is done to seeds before or at the time of planting the germinating seeds and seedlings to protect the seeds from various pests and diseases. Seed Treatment Campaigns were organized in 5 scheduled villages of 5 Gram Panchayats of Kuchinda Block on scheduled dates by ‘ANGEL’ with the support of FIAC and in collaboration with Agriculture Department., Kuchinda.

For the 2nd year, 3 Block Coordinators and 3 Cluster Coordinators were engaged by ANGEL in Kuchinda RWSS Sub-division, Rairakhol RWSS Sub-division and Naktideol RWSS Sub-division of Sambalpur District respectively. Their monthly remuneration and TA received from District Water and Sanitation Mission, Sambalpur is being disbursed by ANGEL.

Recognizing the need for peak season demand for labour and to reduce the costs the Government is encouraging use of appropriate mechanization of agricultural operations. The Government of Odisha is encouraging the farmers to adopt improved farm machinery

For the 3rd year, 3 Block Coordinators and 3 Cluster Coordinators were engaged by ANGEL in Kuchinda RWSS Sub-division, Rairakhol RWSS Sub-division and Naktideol RWSS Sub-division of Sambalpur District respectively. Their monthly remuneration and TA received from District Water and Sanitation Mission Sambalpur is being disbursed by ANGEL.

To enhance capacities of rural youth in addressing the issues and concerns affecting their lives ANGEL organized organised one day Theme based Awareness and Education programme at Kuchinda on Dt.29.03.2016 in which 80 youths from 20 Youth Clubs participated. Under the programme the topics covered on Skill Development, Leadership among rural young people to address issues of local, national and international importance with local youth, PRIs, urban local bodies and community participation.

For the 4thd year, 3 Block Coordinators and 3 Cluster Coordinators were engaged by ANGEL in Kuchinda RWSS Sub-division, Rairakhol RWSS Sub-division and Naktideol RWSS Sub-division of Sambalpur District respectively. ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: After the inception the organization introduced many new activities like dance therapy, creative arts therapy, creative dramatics in education in to the field of disability in the state of odisha. Consequent to that aaina conducted pshycosocial rehabilitation of 3000 children affected by the super cyclone of 1999. Continuing with the work the organization developed the first enumeration of disability in the district of ganjam. Further on aaina extended support to establish 150 SHGs of persons with disability. The organization was extended the coordination task of SHG product marketing by the state govt. The organization is a member of National Trust. Aaina is heading a South Asian campaign named We Can to eliminate violence against women. The organization has always extended humanitarian relief during natural disasters. The organization has been a consulting agency in the state policy for children. Recently the organization has been initiating the establishment of child rights in the riot striffen district of Kandhamal.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: â€œAangikaâ€œwas formed with basic ideology tp promote & propagate the wide range of folk dance & music of Orissa, keeping a focus on the â€œMayurbhanj Chhowâ€. Orissa has an extremely rich heritage in folk dances and theatrical forms. Since its inception this organization has strived hard to promote â€˜Chhowâ€™, â€˜Gotipuaâ€™, â€˜Palaâ€™, â€˜Daskathiaâ€™, â€˜Odishi Kirttanâ€™, â€˜Prahlad Natakaâ€™, etc. through lecture demonstration, seminars and performance held in various district & State level functions. However, â€˜Aangikaâ€™ has also kept training pupils in the â€˜Mayurbhanj Chhowâ€™ style with Sadashiv Pradhan as the chief â€˜Guruâ€™ who is a renowned exponent of this style and has established himself in the national circuit as an eminent â€˜Chhowâ€™ Scholar. Since this organisation is already more than 20 years in existence, it difficult to describe all the activities undertaken within this short space. Here we are briefly describing our activities undertaken within the last three years i:e: 2009-2012. In the year 2009 we had invited an eminent â€˜Odishi Kirtanâ€™ Guru Srijukta Narendra Patsani, on the occasion of Teachers Day to talk about the origin, growth and development of â€˜Odishi Kirtanaâ€™ in Orissa and how Baishnavites were related to this form. He also talked about the classification of this instruments known as Mrudanga (locally called Khola). After his lecturer he had played the instrument and described its Ekaka Bani and Dweta Bani i:e: single handed sound and double handed sound respectively. Our major activity remained training10-15 students in the style of â€œMayurbhanj Chhowâ€. In the year 2010, we thought some different activites like â€˜Palaâ€™-the popular Katha Gayan style of Orissa and the original form of present â€˜Odishiâ€™ dance called Gotipuaâ€™,along with its regular classes as well as performance. So we had invited Guru Gopi Krushna Behera of Banki,Cuttack an eminent master of Gotipua and Sriman Athithi Sahu of Puri district, a Pala Gayak to conduct workshop on his topic. Guru Gopikrushana Behera gave an extensive lecture on the techniques of Gotipua dance and demonstrated them wonderfully. He talked about its origin and how to train children and its process to disciple. Our â€˜Chhowâ€™ classes continued as usual throughout the year. In the year 2011, apart from our regular classes and public performances we had invited an eminent Mardala player of Utkal Sangita Mahavidyalaya ,Bhubaneswar named Guru Dhaneswar Swain. Guru Srijukta Swain described about unusual â€˜bolâ€™s and â€˜talaâ€™s of odishan rhythm system. Apart from Ekatali and Adatali , he also demonstratd different kinds of â€˜bolâ€™s and â€˜talaâ€™s which are similar to â€˜Chhowâ€™ dance tala system. And he also trained our students on how to compose a â€˜talaâ€™ for any musical composition. This year our students in â€˜Chhowâ€™ experimented in adopting basic movements of â€˜Chhowâ€™ into a presentation of â€˜Prahallad Natakaâ€™ under the eminent Guru Sri Krusna Chandra Sahoo. â€˜Chhowâ€™ classes continued.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: Activities of 2014-15 and 2015-16 i) In 2014-15, AFLC has conducted nine financial literacy camps in small towns/ village in Keonjhar district, covering about 900 students, teaching staff and 200 villagers. Further, it organized a special talk on space odyssey by eminent space scientist Dr Arun Misra, Emeritus Professor, Mechanical Engineering, McGill University, Canada, in Anandapur College. ii) In 2015, AFLC conducted two workshops on MSME Financing for banks and co-operative banks/RRBs in collaboration with Bankers Training Solutions, Kolkata. (Director : S.K. Chakraborty, Ex- General Manager of Allahabad Bank). iii) AFLC organised a â€œSeminar on Financial Literacy and Financial Inclusionâ€, on 19 March 2016 in Bhubaneswar participation of around 125 officials from banks (including senior bankers), senior government officials, SME sector, MFIs, regulators ( RBI, SEBI), other financial institution (SIDBI), academicians, and students of business schools. The Seminar was addressed by experts , academicians and administrators viz. Dr Anup Pujari, IAS, Former Secretary, Government of India, Deepak Mohanty, Executive Director, Reserve Bank of India and G Padmanabhan, Chairman, Bank of India. In 2016, AFLC conducted ten workshops including programs held in leading academic institutions viz. Indian Institute of Mass Communication, Dhenkanal, Ravenshaw Collegiate School, Cuttack, Kalinga Institute of Social Sciences ( KISS), Bhubaneswar covering around 4,600 students and teaching staff. On 19 July 2016 (Bank Nationalisation Day), AFLC conducted a financial literacy camp at Koraput with participation from 60 SHG members, RSETI trainees and bank officials. A Souvenir on the Financial Literacy Seminar of 19 March 2016 was released. Programs targeted in 2016-17. Keeping in view the needs of the financial sector and economic needs of the stakeholders,, we propose to conduct the following programs in 2016-17 i) Financial literacy camps / workshops in schools, colleges/ business schools, ITIs and villages. ( 2-3 hours) : 12 programs. ii) One- day Orientation program for trainers of financial literacy programs. ( 4 programs) iii) One-day Orientation Program for young entrepreneurs/start-ups. ( 4 programs) iv) Workshop on MSME Financing (Training Program for bankers)- 2 -3 days. Special Program â€“ Open to academicians, bankers, youth and government officials. 2nd Annual Seminar on Financial Literacy and Financial Inclusion ( 2017).

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: The mission of Action for Protection of Wild Animals is to preserve the plants,animals and communities that represent the diversity of life on earth by protecting the natural resources they need to survive.Alarmingly , natural disasters are on a rising trend as as result of many factors including climate change, rapid environmental degradation in Odisha state. The goal is promoting the rights of traditional and indigenous community, including artisans, fishers, farmers, to sustainable manage their resources. We are also working towards reversing the rapid loss of mangrove forest, life supporting system and promoting a sustainable use of this ecosystem. Our works bring together community participation in implementing ecosystem based adaptation to climate change.Our approaches are also focused o disaster risk reduction programme in coastal villages.It supports innovations in appropriate technologies and sustainable climate resilient livelihoods that help communities supplement their incomes.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: AGRAGAMEE was started in 1987, seeking to understand the paradox of poverty and hunger in a land of abundance. The challenges were immense. There were few roads to reach the villages; hunger and epidemics were inherent part of the yearly cycle; a small community of contractors and landlords reigned supreme, and there was little or no respect for the law. A series of discussions and dialogues with members of the community, leaders, elected representatives helped us understand the multi-layered systems of exploitation, and coercion that local communities suffered. It also opened the doors of perception to local community members to concepts of justice equality and human rights. It also empowered local communities for self-governance . Gradually, our efforts helped to engender a synergy of food and voice, that built up the self-reliance and self-confidence of local communities. Tribal women were the most forthcoming. As they realised that the law gave them equal rights, they threw off their veil of silence and fought against discrimination at home, and for justice to their people. Their leadership has forged new bonds within a disillusioned and marginalised community, bringing about pro-poor and pro-tribal policies and helping to address exploitation and injustice at several levels. Support to village communities helped in the formation of peopleâ€™s organisations, which helped to address the many problems with collective strength. Here again, and enabling fair bargains for the tribal products through collective entrepreneurship. Our efforts for natural resources development and sustainable agriculture helped the community make significant strides towards self-reliance and food security, enabling poor tribal families come out of the poverty-debt-poverty trap. Agragameeâ€™s work in primary and education addressed crucial factor of exclusion and helped thousands of children, youth and adults and specially girls and women learn the three rs, and aspire for a better quality of life by getting higher degrees, finding jobs, and accessing necessary information. Agragamee has committed itself siding with the tribal and other poor communities so that poverty and hunger are eliminated. It has consciously planed various measures to ensure inclusion, focusing on women and girls, in the school and adult education programmes, on the women headed and landless households in our natural resource development and livelihood programmes. We have the following main activities with tangible results: Education and Literacy: Qualitative Primary Education for 5000 children . Agriculture: 2000 families supported on Organic Farming. Nutrition : 2000 Families for Applied Nutrition. Panchayati Raj : Implemented PESA in 10 Tribal Districts. RTI: Implementing a project in 10 Districts, 100GPs and 1000 villages so that community gets information an various government scheme. Vocational Training: Trained 900 youths. Water resources: Constructed 300 Check-dams, Canals, Tanks, Farm Ponds and Lift points. Womenâ€™s Development & Empowerment: Formed 6 Tribal womenâ€™s Federations focusing on Economic empowerment of women. Land Resources: Implemented 30 micro watersheds in Rainfed Areas which included extensive Land Development like Land levelling, bunding and terracing. Renewable energy: 2 microhydels for 100 families in two village and 3000 solar lights distributed.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: Anchalik Grama Vikash Parishad, Nilgiri was formed on 12th May, 1984 in the meeting held at village Pundal in Nilgiri Block and registered under the Societies Registration Act XXI of 1860 on the auspicious day of 14th, November 1984. This organization has been working in Balasore and Mayurbhanj districts to ameliorate the socio-economic conditions of the unprivileged poor tribal, Harijana and other marginal and landless farmers. With some benevolent social activists having technical knowledge and experience on rural development, the organization was spontaneously formed by the people of the area to solve their acute problems.Few months earlier to the formation of the organization; in order to develop their own area, the founder members were organized a seminar and exhibition on Integrated Rural Development in collaboration with Krishi Vigyan Kendra, Balasore (Orissa University of Agriculture and Technology) and District Rural Development Agency, Balasore from the 13th to 15th March, 1984. About five hundred opinion leaders of the surrounding gram panchayats were participated in the programme. Different resolutions were taken in the seminar to develop the area and to implement the programme, there was a resolution to organise the various developmental programmes through a Voluntary Organisation and on the basis of: that Anchalilk Grama Vikash Parishad, Nilgiri Regional Village Development Council was formed as mentioned earlier.AGVP is being organised various socioÂ¬economic developmental programmes for increasing the per capita income of the individuals and simultaneously creating scientific temper among the local people. The activities of the organisation in different fields are mentioned hereinafter. A Women Empowerment & Employment Generation by Self Help Groups (SHGs) B Development of Dryland Farming C Integrated Family Welfare Programme D National Environment Awareness Campaign and Sanitation Drive E Training-Cum-Production Centre (TPC) for Poor and Destitute in Manufacturing Sabai Grass Products F Vocational Training G Promotion of Farm Implements Production and Distribution H Income Generation Programme I Training and Awareness Camp on Yoga & Naturopathy J Awareness on Information Technology in Rural Area K Awareness on Rural Science & Technology L Irradiation of Illiteracy M Cultural Programmes and Sports N Advisory Service to Farmers O Advisory Service to other Voluntary Organisation P Observance of Important Days of the Year The following funding Agencies have supported AGVP in achieving the above fields of activities Foreign Funding Agencies 1. OXFAM (India) Trust 2. Swedish Embassy Others 1. Department of Science & Technology, Govt. of Odisha 2. Department of Social Forestry, Govt. of Odisha 3. District Rural Development Agency, Balsore 7. Sub-Divisional Social Officer, Nilagiri, Balsore 8. Nehru Yuba Kendra, Balasore 9. Integrated Tribal Development Agency (ITDA), Nilagiri, Balasore 10.
